question_text: A technician discovers that changing the print language from PostScript to PCL resolves an issue with incorrect spacing and font rendering. What does this most likely indicate?
answer_options: The printer was low on toner
The printer tray was incorrectly selected
The printer was sent an unsupported page description language
The print head alignment was off
correct_answer: The printer was sent an unsupported page description language
explanation: Mismatched PDLs (like sending PostScript to a PCL-only printer) can cause garbled layout or unreadable characters due to rendering incompatibility.
